1.0: Had the Mishna [only taught the case of a] found object I would've thought
1.1: [by the case of] a found object is when the Rabbis instituted an oath upon him because he'll rationalize and say
1.2: my friend didn't lose anything.(he will only not gain) I will go and grab, and I will split it [the talis] with him
1.3: But, [by] acquisitions that one can't say this, we would say no [since he is a full-fledged thief he would swear falsely. Therefore, we can't make him take an oath]
1.4: And if it taught acquisitions [I would think]that's when they gave him an oath upon him because he'll rationalize and say:
1.5: my friend gave money; as did I
1.6: now, that I need it [the object]. I will take it, and my friend will go and bother to buy another. ...
1.7: But, [by the case of] a found object that one can't say this, we would say no [since he is a full-fledged thief he would swear falsely. Therefore, we can't make him take an oath]. [Therefore both case are]needed.
1.9: And let us see from who he took? (That is, let us ask the seller who he accepted money from) (Rashi explains that a merchant is believed to say who he accepted money from, provided  he only accepted money from one of them. Tosphos argues and says the gemara is asking that the merchant should be considered a sole witness, who should be believed to exempt the one whose claim he corroborates from swearing an oath.)
1.10: No, it's necessary. He accepted from both of them. One willingly and one forced. And we don't know which one is which. (Our text follows Rashi. According to Tos., the correct version is, "he doesn't know." The circumstances ,i.e., he accepted money from both of them is just an explanation why he doesn't remember. According to Rashi, it's irrelevant if he knows. He is only believed when he only accepted money from one of them.

2.0: We should derive that the Mishnah [here] does not follow Rabbi Yossi, for if it were like Rabbi Yossi -- Rabbi Yossi said:
2.1: If so, what did the liar lose?
2.2: Rather it all should be set aside until Elijah comes.
2.5: The remainder will be set aside until Elijah comes. This [case] is similar to the remainder, for it is unclear!
2.6: What kind of comparison is this!?
2.7: If you said, it is easy for the Rabbis, there [the depositor] this maneh certainly belongs to one of them, and the Rabbis said:
2.8: It should be set aside until Elijah comes. Here [the garment], where it could be said that it belongs to both of them, the Rabbis said to split it with an oath.
2.9: But if you said, the Mishnah is according to Rabbi Yossi, there [the depositors] certainly a maneh belongs to one and another maneh belongs to the other, Rabbi Yossi it will be set aside until Elijah comes, here, where we could say that belongs to [only] one of them, all the more so!
2.10: Even if you say it is Rabbi Yossi, there [the depositors] there is certainly a liar, here, who can tell us that there is a liar?
2.11: Say, they simultaneously picked it up.

3.0: Rami Bar Chama said: this [the Mishnah where two pick up a garment] means that:
3.1: Someone who picks up a lost object on behalf of his fellow, his fellow has acquired it.
3.2: For if  you thought his fellow didn't acquire it, then this case would be as if his half is lying on the ground, and his half is lying on the ground, and neither would acquire it. Rather, learn from this:
3.3: Someone who picks up a lost object on behalf of his fellow, his fellow has acquired it.
3.5: Someone who picks up a lost object on behalf of his fellow, his fellow has not acquired it. Rather this is the reason [of our Mishnah]: Since he can acquire it for himself, he can acquire it for someone else.

4.0: The one who drives [a mixture of two species of animals] receives forty [lashes], and the one who sits in the wagon [being pulled by the mixture] receives forty [lashes]. Rabbi Meir exempts the one sitting in the wagon.

5.1: One is riding upon a donkey, and another is holding the reins [without leading it], the former has acquired the donkey, and the latter has acquired the reins.
5.4: [Rather say] that this case is where the rider is driving the donkey with his legs.
5.5: If that is the case [that he is driving it with his legs] he should also acquire the reins [for they are attached to the donkey, which he is moving].
5.7: The former has acquired the donkey and half of the reins.
5.8: And the latter has acquired half of the reins. It makes sense that the rider has acquired [half of the reins], because he has a mentally competent person [=the person holding the reins] lifting it on his behalf, but the person holding the reins - how can he acquire it?
5.10: The former has acquired a donkey and the entirety of the reins, and the latter has acquired that of the reins which is in his hand.
5.12: If you wish to say - "he who lifts a lost object on behalf of his friend, his friend has acquired it" - that is when he lifts it on behalf of his friend. Here, he lifts it on his own behalf. [And even if he lifts it on behalf of his friend,] he cannot acquire it, how can acquire it on behalf of his friend?
5.14: The former has acquired the donkey and the bridle, and the latter has acquired that which is in his hand, and neither of them has acquired the remainder.
5.15: We learn in a Baraita: Rabbi Eliezer says:
5.16: "The rider in the field; and the driver [even] in the city, has acquired it."
5.17: Here too, [let us say that] he is driving it with his legs.
5.18: If so, he is also a driver?
5.19: They are two kinds of drivers.
5.20: If so, why doesn't the rider (who is driving it with his legs) acquire it in the city?
5.22: Because it isn't normal to ride in the city.
5.23: Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana:
5.24: Now, he who lifts a wallet on the Sabbath; for people do not lift wallets on the Sabbath, he too [the one who lifts the wallet] would not acquire it.
5.25: [Because] what he has done, he has done, and acquired it, so too here what he has done, he has done, and acquired.
5.26: Rather, we are dealing with a case of commerce, where he told him:
5.27: Acquire it, in the manner which people acquire it.

6.0: Rav Nachman and Rav Chisda both said:
6.1: He who picks up a lost object on behalf of his fellow -- his fellow has not acquired it.
6.2: What is the reason? [It is as if] he is seizing assets for a lender when the borrower owes others, and one who seizes assets on behalf of a lender when the borrower owes others has not taken possession of the assets.
6.4: That which a worker finds, belongs to himself.
6.5: In regards to what is this said? When the employer told him: Weed for me today; Hoe for me today.
6.7: Work for me today -- then what he finds belongs to the employer.
6.9: A worker is different, for his hand is like the hand of the employer.
6.11: A worker may terminate his employment even in the middle of the day.
6.13: So long as he did not back out [of his job] his hand is like the hand of the employer, and backing out is from a different reason [i.e. not because he is not like the employer] -- as it is written (Leviticus 25, 55): "For unto Me the children of Israel are servants; they are My servants" -- and not servants to servants.

7.1: We'll come back to you, chapter "Two Are Holding".
7.2: Which are the found items that belong to him [the finder], and which ones must he announce? announce.
7.3: These are the found items which belong to him [the finder]:
7.4: if one found scattered fruit, scattered money, sheaves in the public domain, fig-cakes, baker's bread, strings of fish, cuts of meat, wool as it is from the country, bundles of flax and purple wool - these are his [the finder's,] these are the words of Rabbi Meir.
7.6: anything which has on it a change, one must announce.
7.8: If one found a cake with a clay shard in it, or a sheaf with money within it.
7.10: any merchandise, one does not need to declare
7.14: Kav in four amot [presumably four amot squared]
7.16: If the fruit look like they fell, it should be [the finder's] even if there are more than that. If the fruit look like they were placed there, even less than that should be the owner's
7.18: We are talking about the threshing floor.
7.19: Kav in four amot isn't worth the bother of coming back to gather it.
7.20: If there is that amount or less, the owner would give it up and declare it ownerless. If there is more, he'd put in the work of gathering it, so it is not ownerless.
7.22: What if it is half a kav in two amot?
7.23: If the issue is that a kav in four amot is too much work, half a kav in two amot would be less work, and therefore not ownerless.
7.25: Because of the amount? Half a kav in two amot isn't much and it would be ownerless.
7.26: What about two kavs in eight amot?
7.27: If a kav in four amot is too much work, two kavs in four amot are even more work, and the owner would abandon it.
7.29: Because of the amount, two kavs in eight amot is too much and he owner won't abandon it.
7.30: What about a kav of sesame seeds [which are smaller but more valuable?]
7.31: If the issue is how valuable it is, a kav of sesame seeds is valuable, so the owner won't abandon it.
7.33: If the issue is work, a kav of sesame seeds is more work and the owner would definitely abandon it.
7.34: If the rule is about a kav of dates in four amot, what about a kav of pomegranates?
7.35: If the issue is value, and a kav of dates isn't valuable enough for the owner to return, a kav of pomegranates is certainly not valuable enough for the owner to return.
7.37: Because of the work, and a kav of dates would be more work than a kav of pomegrantes, so the kav of pomegrantes wouldn't be ownerless (the owner would return).
7.38: Tiku - we won't know the answer under Elijah the Prophet comes back with the messiah to answer such questions.

9.0: ... ... ... ... ... ... R. Yehuda was doing business after Mar Shmuel in the grain-pounder’s marker. He asked Mar Shmuel, “If a person found a purse here, what is the ruling?  He replied, “It is his.” “And if an Israelite came, and gave him a sign [proving that the lost item was his], what is the ruling?” He replied, “The finder is obligated to return it.” “Both?”  Mar Shmuel said to him “within the line of the law,” for the father of [Mar] Shmuel had once found donkeys in the desert and had returned them to their owner after twelve months had already passed–[he acted] within the line of the law. Rava was following after R. Nachman in the leatherworker’s market–there are those who say [it was] the marketplace of the rabbis–and he asked R. Nachman, “If a person found a purse here, what is the ruling?” He said to him, “It is his.” “And if an Israelite came and gave him a sign, what is the ruling?” He said to him “It is his [it still belongs to the finder].” Wouldn’t he [the Israelite] stand and shout in protest? Such behavior is like one who protests against his house falling, or his ship sinking at sea. ... ... ... ...

10.0: Like the stones of the House of Kolius, what is it (i.e. the law)?
10.1: Come and hear, that we learned (in a braita):
10.2: If one finds money spread out, they are his (to keep); like the stones of the House of Kolius, he is required to announce.
10.3: And these are the stones of the House of Kolius:
10.4: One from here and one from here and one on top of them.
10.6: One who finds a Selah (a type of coin) in the market and his friend finds him and says to him it is mine: it is new; it is a Nero one; (or) it is from so-and-so king, he has not said anything.
10.7: And not more, but even if his name is written on it, he has not said anything because there is no sign for a coin for we say "maybe he put it out (i.e. used it) and it it fell from another man."
10.8: If he found it beyond an [wooden] enclosure, or behind a [stone] fence, or he found chicks tied together, or he found it in the paths in a field -- he should not touch them.
10.9: If he found it in the garbage: if it is covered, he should not touch it; if it is not covered, he takes it and announces that he found it.

11.0: ... ... ... ... ... ... ... Rava said, “In any situation where he would return his own [livestock], he must return those which belong to his friend. In any case where who would load and unload his own property, he must also load and unload that which belongs to someone else.” R. Ishmael, son of R. Yossi, was walking on the road when he came upon a man who was carrying bundles of sticks. The man put them down, and rested. Then he said to R. Ishmael, “Help me pick them up.” He asked him, “How much are they worth?” He said to him, “Half a zuz.”  So R. Ishamel gave him half a zuz, and declared the bundle of sticks ownerless.  But the man took them back for himself. So R. Ishmael again paid him half a zuz, and declared the sticks ownerless. Seeing that the man intended to acquire them for himself again, he said to him: “With respect to the rest of the world, these sticks are ownerless [and anyone can take them]. But with respect to you, they are not ownerless [and you cannot reacquire them].” But if that is the case, who would say it was really ownerless? As it has been taught according to the House of Shammai, items declared ownerless can only be acquired by the poor. According to the House of Hillel, an item only qualifies as ownerless if it can be acquired by rich and poor alike, as in [the case of the rules pertaining to] the sabbatical year. So R. Ishmael the son of R. Yossi did, in fact, declare it ownerless and available to anyone to take! It was by words alone that he stopped him.  But R. Ishmael was an elder, and it was not in accordance with his dignity [to help the man]. R. Ishmael, son of R. Yossi, acted within the line of the law. R. Yosef taught [expounding Ex. 18:20], “You shall make known to them” - this refers to their livelihood; “The path” - this refers to acts of loving-kindness; “They are to walk” - this refers to visiting the sick; “Upon” - this refers to burial; “The deeds” - this refers to the law; “They are to perform” - this refers to [actions] within the line of the law.
11.1: The master [i.e. R. Yosef] said: “They are to walk ” - this refers to visiting the sick. If so, the prooftext for deeds of loving-kindness would appear to be redundant. However, is necessary to include the case of someone visiting a sick person with whom he shares a particular affinity. The master reasoned that one who visits a sick person with whom shares a particular affinity takes one-sixtieth of his illness upon himself, but he must visit him nevertheless.  “Upon it” – this refers to burial. We still would not need to mention [a prooftext for] deeds of loving-kindness, except for the case of an elder, where the task is not in accordance with his dignity. “They are to perform” – this refers to [actions] within the line of the law. R. Yohanan taught, “Jerusalem was destroyed because its inhabitants judged according to the law of Torah.” Should they instead have made arbitrary judgments?! Rather, [the teaching means that] they based their judgments on a strict interpretation of Torah law, instead of acting within the line of the law.

13.0: Mishnah: [If] one deposited [for safekeeping] an animal or vessels with his neighbor and they were stolen or lost, if he paid but did not want to swear [the prescribed oath], since they [the sages] said,
13.1: "An unpaid guardian may swear and [then] be exempt" [from liability]; if the thief is found, [the thief] must pay double.
13.2: [If the thief] butchered or sold the object, he must pay four or fivefold.
13.3: To whom does he pay? To him who the deposit is with.
13.4: [If the guardian] swore the [prescribed oath] and did not want to pay; if the thief is found, he must pay double.
13.5: [If the thief] butchered or sold the object, he must pay four or fivefold.
13.6: To whom does he pay? To the owner of the deposit.
13.7: Gemara: What reason does he have to teach, "animal," and what reason does he have to teach, "vessels," (meaning, why mention both)?
13.8: It is necessary. Since, if he taught [only] "animal," I would have said,
13.9: "It is [in the case of] an animal that [the owner] cedes him the multiple payment, because there is much effort to bring it in and bring it out; but [in the case of] vessels, the effort [required] for which is not much," I would say, He does not cede the multiple payment."
13.10: And if he taught [only] vessels, I would have said,
13.11: "It is [in the case of] vessels that [the owner] cedes him the multiple payment, because their multiple payment is not much; but [in the case of] an animal - that if he slaughters or sells [it] - he pays four of fivefold," I would say, "He does not cede the multiple payment." [Hence,] it is necessary.
13.12: Ram bar Chami strongly objects to it,
13.13: "And behold, a person can not cede something that has not come into the world!
13.14: And even according to Rabbi Meir who says,
13.15: 'A person can cede something that has not come into the world;' those words apply to - for example - fruits of a palm tree that are accustomed to coming, but here

14.0: who is there to say that it will be stolen; and if you find to say that it will be stolen, who is there to say that the thief will be found: and if the thief is found, who is there to say that he will pay - maybe he will admit and be exempt."
14.2: "He becomes like one who said to him,
14.3: 'When if it is stolen and you will want to pay me, behold my cow is ceded to you from now.'"
14.4: Rav Zera objected strongly to it,
14.5: "If so, [that should apply] even to its fleece and its offspring as well!
14.6: So why is it learned [in a berieta],
14.9: "He becomes like one who said to him, 'except for its fleece and offspring.'"
14.10: And why is it [an unqualified] decision [in the mishnah]?
14.11: The unqualified [way] of this matter is [that] the gain that comes from the world, a person is accustomed to cede; the gain that comes from itself, a person is not accustomed to cede.
14.12: There are those that say, "Said Rava,
14.13: 'He becomes like one who said to him, "When if it is stolen and you will want to pay me, adjacent to (before) it being stolen, it is ceded to you."'"
14.14: What is [the difference] between [the two renditions]?
14.15: [The difference] between them is the question of Rabbi Zera [which is not applicable to the second rendition].
14.16: And also (another answer), when it is standing in a marsh.
14.17: [If he paid, and he did not want to swear, etc.]
14.18: Said Rav Chiya bar Abba, "Said Rabbi Yochanan,
14.19: '[It doesn't mean] paid, [as in] actually paid, but rather once he said, "Behold, I will pay," even though he has not [yet] paid.'"
14.21: "If he paid and he did not want to swear:" if he paid, yes; if he did not pay, no!
14.22: I will say the end [of the Mishnah].
14.23: "If he swore and did not want to pay;" the reason is that he did not want to pay - hence if he wanted [to pay], even if he did not [actually] pay [it is as if he paid]!
14.24: But rather from [the mishna] here, we cannot imply [anything] from it.
14.25: It was taught [in a bereita] like Rabbi Yochanan,
14.26: "One who rents a cow from his fellow and it is stolen, and that one says, 'Behold, I am paying and not swearing' and afterwards the thief was found; the thief pays a double payment to the renter."
14.28: "An unpaid guardian - once he said, 'I have been negligent,' [the owner] cedes the multiple payment to him. Since, if he wanted, he could have exempted himself with [the claim of] theft.
14.29: A paid guardian - once he said, 'It was stolen,' [the owner] cedes the multiple payment to him. Since, if he wanted, he could have exempted himself with [the claim of] broken or died.
14.30: A borrower who says, 'Behold I will pay,' [the owner] does not cede him the multiple payment.
14.31: With what could he have exempted himself? With [a claim of] it died on account of work? 'It died on account of work' [however] is not common [and, so, an unlikely claim]."
14.33: 'A borrower also - once he says, "Behold I will pay," [the owner] cedes him the multiple payment. Since, if he wanted, he could have exempted himself with [the claim of] it died on account of work.'"
14.34: Said Rav Zevid to him, "Thus said Abaye,
14.35: 'A borrower [is not ceded the payment] until he pays.'"
14.36: What is the reason? Because all of the benefit [goes to the borrower, the owner] will not cede him the multiple payment based on words.
14.37: It was taught [in a bereita] like Rav Zevid,
14.38: "One who borrows the cow of his fellow and it is stolen, and the borrower hastens and pays; and afterwards the thief is found, [the thief] pays a double payment to the borrower."
14.39: For the first [variation] of Rav Pappa, it is certainly not a refutation. [But] for the second [variation], shall we say that it is a refutation?
14.40: Rav Pappa would say to you,
14.41: "Is [your bereita, the source of your refutation] stronger than our mishnah, that taught, 'he paid' and I established [that it meant], he said [that he would pay].
14.42: Here [in the bereita] too, it is that he said [that he would pay]."
14.44: There, it was not learned, "he hastened;" here it was learned, "he hastened!"
14.45: What is [the meaning] of "he hastened?" He hastened and said.
14.46: Behold, since it learned concerning the renter, "and he said," and concerning the borrower, "he hastened;"
14.47: we infer from it, that it was teaching precisely [and "hastened" did not mean, hastened and said].
14.48: Were [the two statements] learned together [such that one could make the last observation]?
14.49: We asked this to the teachers [who were experts on such statements] of the House of Rabbi Chiya and the House of Rabbi Oshaya, and they said,
14.51: It is obvious [that in a case where the guardian] said, "I will not pay," and [then] he went back and said, "Behold, I will pay," [that he acquires the multiple payment from the thief should it be received];
14.52: Behold, he said, "Behold, I will pay." But [in a case where] he said, "Behold I will pay,"

15.3: [Also, in a case where] he says, "Behold I will pay," and he dies, and his children say, "We will not pay," what [is the law]?

16.5: "[It is when] there are witnesses that it was stolen."

16.7: [He may do so if] he expends effort [to retrieve it] and brings it.
16.8: If so, when the creditor swears too, the borrower may expend effort and bring it.
16.9: It is understood concerning the creditor - he knows who comes in and goes out of his home, and [so he can] go and expend effort and bring it; but does the borrower know who comes in and goes out of the creditor's home?
16.11: "It is a decree, lest [the creditor] claim and say,
16.12: 'I found it after [I took] the oath [of Rav Huna].'"
16.14: "This one swears and that one swears: this one swears that it is not in his possession and that one swears [about] how much it was worth."
16.15: And this is what [the] mishnah is saying:
16.16: "Who should swear first? The creditor swears first, lest [the lender] will swear and [the creditor] take out the deposit."
16.17: Rav Huna bar Tachlifa said in the name of Rava
16.18: "The beginning of the end [of the mishnah] is a refutation of Rav Huna:
16.19: '"You lent me a sela on it, and it was worth two," and this one says,
16.20: "No, but rather I lent you a sela on it, and it was worth a sela," he is exempt.'
16.21: And if [the oath of] Rav Huna existed, on the back of that which the creditor swears that it is not in his possession, let him also swear [about] how much it was worth because of [the concept of] the superimposition of oaths (gilgul shevua)."
16.23: "I recounted this discussion in front of Rav Kahana, and he said to me,
16.24: 'Let it be [a case] of [the borrower] believes [the creditor].'"
16.25: And let the borrower believe the creditor also about how much it was worth!
16.26: It did not sit with [the creditor long enough that he can trust his appraisal].
16.27: And let the creditor believe the borrower, with whom it sat with [long enough that he would know its appraisal]!
16.29: And what is the difference, that the borrower believes the creditor and the creditor does not believe the borrower?
16.30: The lender [understands] the creditor as a fulfillment of (Proverbs 11:3), "The innocence of the straight will guide them;" the creditor [understands] the borrower as a fulfillment of  (ibid.), "the crookedness of the traitors will despoil them."
16.31: A certain man deposited nose-rings with his fellow. [Later, the former] said to [the latter], "Give me my nose-rings."
16.33: "I don't know where I put them."
16.34: He came in front of Rav Nachman, [who] said to him,
16.35: "Any, 'I don't know' is negligence. Go and pay."
16.36: He did not pay. [So] Rav Nachman went and seized his house from him.
16.37: In the end, the nose-rings were found and they had appreciated.
16.39: "Let the nose-rings be returned to their owner, and the house returned to its owner."
16.41: "I was sitting in front of Rav Nachman and it was [during the time of the study] of our chapter [entitled] Hamafkid, and I said to him,
16.42: '"He paid and did not want to swear, [...If (the thief) butchered or sold the object, he must pay four or fivefold. To whom does he pay? To him who the deposit is with." So why would the guardian in Rav Nachman's case not keep the appreciation?]'
16.43: And he did not answer me.
16.44: And it is well that he did not answer me.
16.45: What is the reason? Over there, he did not burden the court; here he burdened the court."
16.46: Is this to say, that Rav Nachman holds that that which is evaluated [as compensation for an unpaid debt] must be returned [once the debtor produces the money]?
16.47: It is different over there, since it was a mistaken evaluation, as the nose-rings were there from the beginning.
16.49: "An evaluation must be returned for up to twelve months of a year."
16.51: "I am from Nehardea and I hold that an evaluation must always be returned."
16.53: an evaluation must always be returned,
16.54: on account of that which is stated (Deuteronomy 6:18), "And you will do the straight and the good."
16.55: It is obvious [that] if they evaluated [and seized property to repay] a creditor and he went and had it evaluated [and gave it to repay] his creditor, we say to [that creditor],
16.56: "You are not better than the man that you came from."
16.57: [But if the first creditor] sold it, bequeathed it or gave it as a gift, these came to it with the intention of [acquiring] land and did not come to it with the intention of [acquiring] money.
16.58: [And] if they appraised a debt [and accordingly seized property] for a woman of if they appraised a debt [and accordingly seized property] from a woman and she married and died, the husband is [considered] a purchaser [of this property] - he does not return it and they do not return it to him.
16.59: Since Rabbi Yose bar Chaninah had said,
16.61: 'If a woman sold her usufrucht (melog) properties during the lifetime of her husband and she dies, the husband can extract them from the hand of purchasers.'"

17.0: If [the debtor, however,] ceded [property to repay] his debt, about this Rav Acha and Ravina disagreed:
17.2: "It must be returned [when he produces money]" and one said,
17.4: The one that said it must not be returned reasons
17.5: that this is a fine sale, as he ceded it of his own volition.
17.6: And the one that said it must be returned reasons
17.7: that this is not a fine sale,  and that which he ceded it of his own volition and did not come to court was on account of his embarrassment - [that's why] he ceded it.
17.8: And from when can [the creditor] eat the fruits [of the land seized]?
17.10: "From when the bill of expropriation comes to his hand." Abbaye said,
17.11: "His witnesses acquire it for him with their signing it."
17.13: "When the days of [the bill's] announcement are completed."
17.14: Mishnah: If one rented a cow from his fellow, and loans it to another, and the cow dies naturally; the one who rented [the cow] should swear that it died naturally, and the borrower should pay the renter.
17.16: "How shall he do business with his fellow's cow?
17.17: Rather, the cow [or its value] must be returned to the owners."
17.18: Gemara: Said Rav Idi bar Avin to Abbaye,
17.19: "Because of what - with what did the renter acquire this cow? With an oath. And let the owner say to the renter,
17.20: 'Drop yourself and drop your oath, and I will make the claim against the renter.'"
17.22: "Do you hold that it is with the oath that the renter acquires it?
17.23: It is from the time of death that he acquires it and the oath is to ease the mind of the owner."
17.25: "There are times when the owners pay for several cows to the renter."
17.27: If he rented it from him for a hundred days and [the owner] went back and borrowed it for ninety days;
17.28: [and now the renter] went back and rented it for eighty days and [the owner] went back and borrowed if for seventy days, and it died during the days of its [last] borrowing -
17.29: [this is such a case,] since he is obligated [to pay the value of] one cow for each borrowing.
17.30: Rav Acha of Difti said to Ravina,
17.31: "Because of what - it is one cow! It went in and it went out: it went out from being rented and went into being borrowed, [then] it went out from being borrowed and went into being rented."
17.33: "And does the cow exist intact that he can say thus?"
17.35: "He only has [a claim for] two cows on them - one is for borrowing and one is for renting, [as] there is one classification for borrowing and one classification for renting. The [cow] of borrowing he has completely acquired; the [cow] of renting, he works with it (or its replacement) for the days of its rental and he returns it to its owner."
17.37: "There are times that both of them are [obligated to sacrifice] a sin offering;

18.0: there are times that both of them are [obligated to sacrifice] a guilt offering; there are times when the renter [is obligated to sacrifice] a sin offering and the borrower a guilt offering; [and] there are times when the renter [is obligated to sacrifice] a guilt offering and the borrower a sin offering."
18.2: The [false] denial of [a debt requires] a guilt offering, a [false] utterance of the lips [requires] a sin offering:
18.3: "There are times that both of them are [obligated to sacrifice] a sin offering" - for example, it died naturally, and they said it was [the result] of an accident.
18.4: The renter - that [whether] it is this or that is exempt [from paying] - [needs to sacrifice] a sin offering; the borrower - that [whether] it is this or that is obligated [to pay] - [needs to sacrifice] a sin offering.
18.5: "There are times that both of them are [obligated] a guilt offering" - for example, it was stolen and they said that it died on account of work. As both of them are denying [a debt], since behold they are obligated [to pay] and they have exempted themselves.
18.6: "The renter [is obligated] a sin offering and the borrower a guilt offering" - for example, it died naturally, and they said, it died on account of work.
18.7: The renter - that [whether] it is this or that is exempt [from paying] - [needs to sacrifice] a sin offering; the borrower, that is obligated [to pay] when it dies naturally, and exempted himself [with the claim] that it died on account of work [is obligated] a guilt offering.
18.8: "The renter [is obligated] a guilt offering and the borrower a sin offering" - for example, it was stolen and they said that it died naturally.
18.9: The renter, who is obligated [to pay] for theft and loss and exempted himself [with the claim] that it died naturally [is obligated] a guilt offering.
18.10: The borrower - that [whether] it is this or that is obligated [to pay] - [is obligated] a sin offering.
18.11: What do we learn from here?
18.12: To exclude [the opinion] of Rabbi Ami, who said,
18.13: "Any oath that the judges make one swear, we do not obligate [a sin offering] on account of an oath of utterance, as it is stated (Leviticus 5:4), 'or a person, if he swears to utter with the lips' - 'if he swears' on his own."
18.14: We learn from [the cases above] that [the law] is not like Rabbi Ami.
18.15: It was stated, "A guardian that passes on [what he is guarding] to a guardian:
18.17: '[The first guardian] is exempt [from any liability that he did not originally have].' But Rabbi Yochanan said,
18.20: "According to the reasoning of Rav, it is not necessary [to say] an unpaid guardian who passes it on to a paid guardian, as he raises [the level of] its guarding;
18.21: but rather even a paid guardian who passes it on to an unpaid guardian, [and so] lowers [the level of] its guarding, is exempt.
18.22: What is his reason? That, behold, he gave it to a mentally competent one.
18.23: And according to the reasoning of Rabbi Yochanan, it is not necessary [to say] a paid guardian who passes it on to an unpaid guardian, as he lowers [the level of] its guarding; but rather even an unpaid guardian who passes it on to a paid guardian, [and so] raises [the level of] its guarding, is liable.
18.25: 'It is not my wish that my deposit be in the hand of another.'"
18.27: "Behold [the opinion just attributed to] Rav was not stated explicitly, but rather [only] implied:
18.28: For these gardeners would deposit their hoes with this elderly woman.
18.29: One day one [of the gardeners] deposited them with [another] one of them. [The latter then] heard the sound of a wedding party - [so] he went out and deposited them with the elderly woman.
18.30: Before he went and came back, the hoes were stolen.
18.31: He [then] went in front of Rav and [Rav] exempted him.
18.32: The one who saw [this] reasoned [that it was] on account of a guardian who passed it on to a guardian that he was exempt, but it was not [on account of that].
18.33: It was different over there, as also every [other] day, they themselves would deposit [the hoes] with the elderly woman.
18.34: Rabbi Ami sat and recounted this discussion. Rav Abba bar Mammel objected to Rabbi Ami [about Rabbi Yochanan's position],
18.35: [The mishnah, however, states,] "If one rented a cow from his fellow, and loans it to another, and the cow dies naturally; the one who rented [the cow] should swear that it died naturally, and the borrower should pay the renter."
18.37: "What are we dealing with here [in the mishnah]?" In [a case] that they gave him (the permission of the owners) to lend it out."
18.38: If so, [the borrower] needs to pay the owners.
18.39: [It is a case] that they said to him,
18.40: "It is according to your judgment [to decide who to lend it to]."
18.41: Rami bar Chama objected [from another mishnah],
18.42: "'The one who deposited coins with his neighbor, and he tied them up [in a package] and carried it over his shoulder, or he entrusts them to his minor son or daughter, and locked it up before them [in a way] that was not satisfactory, he is liable, because he did not guard [them] in the manner of guardians.'
18.43: The reason is that they were minors.
18.44: [But according to Rabbi Yochanan,] why [should that be]?
18.45: [Even if they were not minors,] let [the owner] say to him,
18.46: ''It is not my wish that my deposit be in the hand of another!'"

19.0: deposits with the intention [that it can also be guarded by the guardian's] wife and children."
19.2: "[Rava's teaching] is also precise, as it is taught [in the mishnah],
19.3: 'or he entrusts them to his minor son or daughter[...], he is liable.'
19.4: Behold [it can be inferred], to his adult son or daughter, he is exempt.
19.5: [So] it is implied that to others, there is no difference if they are adults or minors, he is liable.
19.6: Since if [it did make a difference with others as well], let it teach 'minors' without differentiation. We learn from this [that the mishnah is only making the allowance for (adult) children]."
19.8: "The law is that a guardian that passes it on to a guardian is liable -
19.9: it is not necessary [to say] a paid guardian who passes it on to an unpaid guardian, as he lowers [the level of] its guarding;
19.10: but rather even an unpaid guardian who passes it on to a paid guardian is liable. What is the reason? It is that [the owner] can say to him,
19.11: 'I believe you with an oath; I do not believe that one with an oath.'"
19.12: It was stated, "If [the guardian] is negligent and [the animal in his charge] goes out to the marsh and dies naturally:
19.13: Abbaye said in the name of Rabbah,
19.14: 'He is liable.' Rava said in the name of Rabbah,
19.16: Abbaye said in the name of Rabbah,
19.17: "He is liable - any judge that does not judge like this law is not a judge.
19.18: It is not necessary [to say that] according to the one that says if its beginning is negligent but its end is accidental he is liable, that he is liable.
19.19: But rather even according to the one that says he is exempt, here he is liable.
19.21: The vapors of the marsh killed it."
19.22: Rava said in the name of Rabbah,
19.23: 'He is exempt - any judge that does not judge like this law is not a judge.
19.24: It is not necessary [to say that] according to the one that says
19.25: if its beginning is negligent but its end is accidental he is exempt, that he is exempt.
19.26: But rather even according to the one that says he is liable, here he is exempt.
19.28: [For] the angel of death, what [difference is it] if he is here or there?"
19.29: And Abbaye concedes that if it came back to the house of its master and died, he is exempt.
19.30: What is the reason? That behold, it came back and one cannot say, the vapors of the marsh killed it.
19.31: And Rava concedes, in any case that a thief steals it in the marsh and it dies naturally in the thief's home that he is liable.
19.32: What is the reason? [Even] if the angel of death would leave it, it is sitting in the house of the thief.
19.34: "According to you, who said, '[For] the angel of death, what [difference is it] if he is here or there;' that which Rav Abba bar Mammel objected to Rabbi Ami, and he answered him, 'It is in [a case] that they gave him the permission of the owners to lend it out.' Let him rather say,
19.35: '[For] the angel of death, what [difference is it] if he is here or there?'"
19.37: "To you, who taught [that the reason for Rabbi Yochanan's ruling was that the owner could say,] 'It is not my wish that my deposit be in the hand of another,' there is what to object to it; [but] to me, since I say [the reason is that the owner could say,] 'I believe you with an oath; I do not believe that one with an oath,' there is nothing to object at all."
19.38: Rami bar Chama objected [to Abbaye's ruling from a mishnah],
19.39: "'If he brought it up to the top of the cliffs and it fell and died, it is not an accident,' and he is liable.
19.40: Behold [it can be inferred], if it died naturally [on the top of the cliffs], it is an accident, and he is exempt.
19.42: Let him say, 'it is the air of the mountain that killed it.' And also 'the exertion of the mountain killed it.'"
19.43: What are we dealing with here [in the mishnah]? That he took it up [the mountain] to a rich and good pasture [and so the beginning was not negligent].
19.44: If so, when it fell [he should] also [be exempt]!
19.45: He should have controlled it and he did not control it.
19.46: If so, I will say the beginning [of the mishnah],
19.47: "If it went up to the top of the cliffs and fell, this constitutes an accident." [But according to you, he should have controlled it.]
19.48: No, it was needed [to be understood as a different case] - [the animal] overpowered him and went up, it overpowered him and went down.
19.49: [Said Rabbi Yose,"How shall he do business with the cow of, etc."]
19.52: Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda said to Rav Yehuda, "You have told us in the name of Shmuel,

20.0: also in the first [case of the chapter].'
20.1: Is the law like him [there] or is the law not like him?"
20.3: "Rabbi Yose was in disagreement also in the first [case] and the law is like him also in the first [case]."
20.4: It was also stated, "Said Rabbi Elazar,
20.5: 'Rabbi Yose was in disagreement also in the first [case] and the law is like him also in the first [case].'
20.7: 'Rabbi Yose conceded in the first [case], as [the renter] had already paid.'"
20.8: If he paid, yes; [but] if he had not paid, no?
20.9: And did Rabbi Chiya bar Abba not say that Rabbi Yochanan said,
20.10: '[It doesn't mean] paid, [as in] actually paid, but rather once he said, "Behold, I will pay," even though he has not [yet] paid.'"
20.11: I will [then] say [that what was actually meant was],
20.12: "Rabbi Yose conceded in the first [case], as [the renter] had already said, 'Behold, I will pay.'"
20.13: Mishnah: If someone said to two people,
20.14: "I robbed a maneh (one hundred zuz) from one of you, but I don't know which one of you;"
20.15: or, "The father of one of you deposited a maneh with me, but I don't know which one;" he must give this one maneh and this one maneh, as he admitted [it] with his own mouth.
20.16: If two [people] deposited money with one; one has deposited a maneh and the other two hundred zuz, [and afterwards] one says, "The two hundred zuz are mine," and the other one says: "The two hundred zuz are mine," [the guardian] shall give a maneh to one and a maneh to the other, and the balance shall be put aside until Eliyahu comes.
20.18: "If so, what did the deceiver lose?
20.19: Rather, everything shall be put aside until Eliyahu comes.
20.20: And also [in a case of] two vessels, the value of one is a maneh, and the value of the other is a thousand zuz. One says, "The [more] valuable is mine," and the other one says, "The [more] valuable is mine." He shall give the small [vessel] to one of them, and from the large [vessel], he shall give the value of the small [vessel] to the other, and the balance shall be put aside until Eliyahu comes. Said Rabbi Yose,
20.21: "If so, what did the deceiver lose?
20.22: Rather, everything shall be put aside until Eliyahu comes."
20.23: Gemara: Apparently, then, [from the first part of the mishnah, we see that]
20.24: we extract money [based on] a doubt, and we do not say, "let the money stand in the possession of its [current] owner."
20.25: But they raised an objection [from another part of the mishnah],
20.26: "If two [people] deposited money with one; one has deposited a maneh and the other two hundred zuz, [and afterwards] one says, "The two hundred zuz are mine," and the other one says: "The two hundred zuz are mine," [the guardian] shall give a maneh to one and a maneh to the other, and the balance shall be put aside until Eliyahu comes."
20.28: "You are objecting from a [case of] theft to a [case of] deposit!
20.29: A theft, wherein he violated a prohibition, the rabbis penalized; a deposit, wherein he did not violate a prohibition, the rabbis did not penalize!"
20.30: But [rather] raise an objection from a deposit to a deposit and raise an objection from a theft to a theft. From a deposit to a deposit, as it was taught in the beginning [of the mishnah],
20.31: "'The father of one of you deposited a maneh with me, but I don't know which one;' he must give this one maneh and this one maneh;"
20.32: and they raised an objection [from the mishnah, as above],
20.35: "[In the case at] the beginning [of the mishnah], [the guardian] becomes like someone who had deposits made in two bundles, wherein he should have checked;
20.36: [In the case at] the end, he becomes like someone who had deposits made in one bundle, wherein he did not have to check - for example, if both of them deposited together at one time, such that he will say to them,
20.37: 'You yourselves were not particular with each other, [if so,] should I be particular?'"
20.38: And raise an objection from [the case of] a theft to a theft: We learned here [in the mishnah],
20.39: "If someone said to two people,'I robbed a maneh from one of you, but I don't know which one of you;' or, 'The father of one of you deposited a maneh with me, but I don't know which one;' he must give this one maneh and this one maneh;"
20.40: and they raised an an objection [from another mishnah],
20.41: "[If] an individual stole from one of five people but does not know from which [of them] he stole, [and] each one says, 'He robbed me' - he places the stolen object among them and withdraws, these are the words of Rabbi Tarfon."
20.42: Apparently, then, [from this last mishnah, we see that]
20.43: we do not extract money [based on] a doubt, and we say,
20.44: "let the money stand in the possession of its [current] owner."
20.45: And from what [do you know] that the mishnah of here is [also the position of] Rabbi Tarfon [and so can be challenged by a mishnah authored by Rabbi Tarfon]? Since it was taught about [that mishnah],
20.46: "Rabbi Tarfon concedes when someone said to two people, 'I robbed a maneh from one of you, but I don't know which one of you,' that he must give this one maneh and this one maneh;"
20.47: [The resolution of the objection is that in the case wherein he places the stolen money among them and withdraws], it is that they sued him. Here (in our mishnah), he has come to fulfill [his obligation] to the Heavens.
20.48: [This answer] is also precise, as [in our mishnah, the reason for the verdict that] is taught [is], "as he admitted [it] with his own mouth." It is inferred from this [that this is a case wherein he was willing to do more than just his obligation].
20.51: but the other (the thief), what did he claim?"
20.53: 'The other was silent.'" Rav Matena [said], "said Rav,

21.1: [According to] the one that says he yelled out, [in a case where he was quiet] however, 'silence is like admission.' And [according to] the one that says he was silent, the silence of here is not 'like admission;' as he is able to say to him,
21.2: That which I was silent to each and every one is because I said,
21.3: "Maybe this one is he [to whom it actually belongs]."
21.5: "'He places the stolen object among them and withdraws;'
21.6: and [so] they all take it and go away.
21.7: And did not Rabbi Abba bar Zivda say that Rav said,
21.8: 'Any possessions in doubt placed [somewhere that makes it appear that it may belong to someone]; ab initio, he should not take; and if he took [it], he should not return [without clear proof of ownership]?'"
21.10: "[The mishnah meant] that 'he should place it' [somewhere for safekeeping]."
21.12: "Did Rabbi Akiva [not] say, "This is not the way to prevent him from sin, rather he must pay [the value of] the stolen object to each one?" Apparently, then,
21.13: [from here we see that] we extract money [based on] a doubt, and we do not say,
21.14: "let the money stand in the possession of its [current] owner."
21.15: But they raised an objection [from another mishnah],
21.16: "A house fell upon a man and upon his mother. The son's heirs
21.17: say, 'The mother died first,' but the mother's heirs say,
21.18: 'The son died first.' Both these [Beit Shammai] and these [Beit Hillel] concede that they split [the property].
21.20: 'I concede here [to Beit Hillel's view in most situations of this type] that the property remains in its current status.'"
21.22: "There it is [a case of the claims having a basis of] maybe and maybe, [but in the case of] 'one stole from five,' it is certain and maybe."
21.23: But behold, our mishnah from here said, "I robbed a maneh from one of you, but I don't know which one of you;'" [and] that is a [case of] maybe and maybe, and it was taught,
21.24: "He must give this one maneh and this one maneh!"
21.25: And from where [do you know that our mishnah is] of Rabbi Akiva? Since it was taught about [the mishnah],
21.26: "Rabbi Tarfon concedes when someone said to two people, 'I robbed a maneh from one of you, but I don't know which one of you,' etc.;"
21.27: To who is he conceding? Is it (not) to Rabbi Akiva his opponent?
21.28: And from where [do you know that our mishnah is a case of] maybe and maybe?
21.30: since it was not taught, " they sue him."
21.31: [And also,] behold, Rabbi Chiya taught [in a parallel bereita],
21.32: "This one says, 'I do not  know' and this one says, 'I do not know.'"
21.33: [The resolution of the standing objection on the position of Rabbi Akiva is,] behold, you have established [that the case in our mishnah] is [when] he has come to fulfill [his obligation] to the Heavens.
21.35: "And did Rava say [that in] all [cases of] two bundles, he should check?
21.36: And behold, said Rava - and if you want to say [it was] Rav Pappa -
21.37: "Everyone concedes in [a case of] two that deposited [sheep] with a shepherd, that the shepherd places it among them and withdraws."
21.39: "There, it is when they deposited [their sheep] into the flock of the shepherd without his knowledge."

22.0: It is better for a man to have relations with a doubtfully married woman than to embarrass your friend in public.
22.1: From where does he get this?
22.4: What can be derived from this biblical source: “But when I halt they rejoice, and gather themselves together; The abjects gather themselves together against me, and those whom I know not; They tear me, and cease not; (Psalms 36:15)”
22.5: David said in front of the Holy One
22.6: "If they tore my flesh, my blood would not spill on the land,
22.7: and not only that, but also in a time when we were dealing with the laws of צרעת and corpses they asked me,
22.8: “The one who committed adultery, in what is his death?”
22.10: “His death is in strangulation. He has a spot in עולם הבא, but the one who embarrasses does not have a place."

30.0: [Necessary items that have been seized by the Beis Hamikdash because of an outstanding vow of Erchin] ought to be returned when needed, kal vachomer from one who owes money to one's fellow:
30.1: If one who owes money, the court does not seize their property, but [if he gave a collateral] it must be returned when needed, how much more so in the case of Hekdesh, which does seize property.
30.2: [But]the verse states; "he (the debtor) shall sleep in his robe (which was a collateral, to be returned each night) and he will bless you" - this does not include Hekdesh, which does not need a brachah
30.4: for the verse (Deut. 8:1) states: "you shall eat, and be satiated, and bless the Lord your God..."
30.5: rather, the verse (Deut. 24:13) continues "and to you it shall be counted as charity"- referring to one who needs [the merit of giving] charity this does not include Hekdesh, which does not require [the merit of giving] charity.
